I have been involved with selling infrared based fiberoptic sensors from as far back as the early 80s. The infrared was at the invisible wavelength frequency, but if you turned on a camcorder you could see it. Pretty amazing laws of physics that are displayed regarding light, attenuation of that light when it comes to different mediums that you shine the light through such as dust, water, glass, and on and on. We then made UV sensors with fiberoptics attached. The inexpensive versions are acrylic, but true glass was the way to go.

One quick correction. The fiber optic example is not (entirely) total internal reflection, since you can see light coming out along the length of the fiber. If it was TRULY total internal reflection, it would ONLY be visible at the end of the fiber. The reason you see light escape from the sides, is that surface roughness along the fiber allows some light to escape via refraction (and when you bend the fiber you change the reflection angles, and breach the total internal reflection threshold, causing refraction).

Destin does an excellent job showing how the principles of fiber optics work in an intuitive way. Some of the earliest experiments that led to what we know as fiber optics today began by observing how light was contained in the streams of illuminated water fountains in the late 1800s. As for transmitting an image using fiber optics, the technology has actually been around since the 1950s. They are called "image guides" are used in the medical industry (endoscopes), the military, and some other industrial applications.

532nm green laser pointers are made with an 808nm infrared diode and a frequency doubling crystal. These crystals are very inefficient, and so often the infrared diodes are WAY overpowered to produce a useful amount of green. The thing is, a TON of infrared can "leak" from these laser pointers and cause SEVERE eye damage that your 532nm glasses probably do not protect against.

Deal with Snells Law every day while performing ultrasonic weld inspection. Once a sound wave is refracted it creates a shear wave along with the initial refracted longitudinal wave. Really cool video man! I have two comments about reflection and angles, feel free to skip if you aren't interested in the technicalities, or do know them.
4:55 So when we talk about angles in optics, we calculate the angle from the normal with respect to the optical boundary, ie, the surface of the lake, or the glass. So, the angle is not under the angle of incidence, but over the critical angle. The angle made by the light beam wrt the normal is called the angle of incidence.
11:27 the beam shouldn't get lighter and lighter as you point the beam up more. When you are pointing the beam up more and more, you are actually decreasing the angle of incidence (wrt normal). Now, at all angles greater than the critical angle, all light reflects, so there shouldn't be a change in the intensity as you keep tilting the laser, until after the angle of incidence, when light starts coming out. Even then, a portion of the light is reflected into the lake, it's just too faint to notice. Thus technically, the light coming out of the lake will increase in intensity as you point the beam more upwards; but this happens only after passing the critical angle.

I made an interesting experiment many years ago.  I learned about TIR and Snell's Law in high school when I was about 15.  I figured the 3D geometry cone and predicted what Destin called the round Snell's window.  So I checked it out one night in a friend's outdoor swimming pool.  The pool was lit up underwater, all surfaces were blue.  I gently entered the water with goggles, trying not to disturb the surface, and went to the bottom, alone in the pool.  Sure enough, TIR made the water-air interface all blue, a perfect reflection of the inside of the pool.  I felt like I was floating inside a large blue box, all alone in this weird world. The world I knew was outside, visible only through a mostly black circle on the top surface.  (It was night so the circle was mostly black.)  So cool.  Then I went up to return to the known world via that circular black door.  To my horror, the circle got smaller.  I started to panic, but the faster I went, the faster the door was closing.  (Check out the geometry.)  just as it closed, locking me inside the blue box forever, my head popped out of the water and the world returned to normal.  Oh, to be 15 again!

As a former Wide Area Network engineer, it was my job, among many others, to ensure that the laser (OC-12) would bounce its way to the destination without signal loss. What was great about the networking protocol called Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) was that if you were on the backbone or fiber, no one else could be on it. So there was never laser collisions and as it was all at the speed of light and asynchronous transmission, it was a blast! When we had a break somewhere on the backbone, it was my job to find it and then hire a contractor to polish the broken ends and reattachment them. It was a major ordeal but so fascinating, I didn't care!

This video is a very fun example of engineers and scientists playing—no foul at all as lots of important discoveries happened this way!

As a Class IV Laser technician, you didn’t need those goggles for that type of laser (handheld) since you were diffusing the beam through acrylic. The only way it would damage your eyes is through direct contact, or indirect contact from a mirror. But with the refraction caused by the acrylic, the comparatively small amount of light that would be hitting your eye wouldn’t do much in small amounts like you did here. But at least you wanted to be safe :)

It's got to be said - Destin's enthusiasm and joy at figuring out, testing and playing with the world and all the amazing things in it is truly infectious.
The sheer delight, almost bursting out of him as he watches a laser reflect off the surface of some water, or illuminating the little globe as it hit the meniscus, can pry and dig its way through the prickliest bad mood and soon enough, you're entranced as well.
I know exactly what's happening - I remember all of this stuff from High School Physics and saw much drier versions of these demonstrations back then. Seeing it performed by a guy who's exploding with happiness that he gets to see this stuff, and overjoyed that he gets to share it with other people makes the whole exercise a LOT more fun however.

"Suppose you want to store energy in empty space rather than a battery. It's easy to think of compacting lots of photons into space. What you need, is either a black hole, or a superreflector. All modern materials have non-100% reflectance. For example, silver has 98.2% for 550 nm wavelength. So, a hypothesis: a material exists with very close to 100% reflectance (similar to superconductivity, and superfluidity), so that light bounces around almost indefinitely inside of it." Call it "superreflectance". Now, I wonder, what are the materials, that are known, which are closest to superreflectors in visible light spectrum.... Or maybe we just need to slow down the light -- e.g., "In 1998, Danish physicist Lene Vestergaard Hau led a combined team from Harvard University and the Rowland Institute of Science, which succeeded in slowing a beam of light to about 17 meters per second,and researchers at UC Berkeley slowed the speed of light traveling through a semiconductor to 9.7 kilometers per second in 2004. Hau later succeeded in stopping  light completely, and developed methods by which it can be stopped and  later restarted."

This was an awesome video- acrylic bars and lasers in a kayak at night, with filming equipment. Its adorable seeing an engineer be amazed by TIRf. TIRf has all kinds of amazing properties- laser light is polarized, and so interestingly, with p-polarized incidence, the evanescent e-wave from the surface can "cartwheel" producing elliptical polarization. In microscopy, the fact that the evanescent wave penetration depth can be less than the wavelength of incident light has revolutionized single molecule imaging and tracking, owing to the huge increase in signal to noise. TIRf with immiscible liquids of different refractive indices is another fun thing to try...too bad Destin didn't have a huge drum of vegaetable oil on the kayak....

Destin, A question was presented to me and my crew involving orbital motions between planetary objects and their satellites in reference to revolution times. We are coming to a split decision as to whether who is "correct" and are hoping that you may be able to apply a solid scientific standard to identify which is fact; or who is "more" correct.



The question presented was, "Given our earth, and referencing a satellite locked into a geostationary orbit, how long does it take for the satellite to complete one revolution around the earth?"


We have come to two points of conclusion:


1. That a satellite is in an orbit around the earth, regardless of whether it is a geostationary or not. It develops that orbit by creating a motion path that "encircles" the earth and therefore follows the rules for a geosynchronous orbit time which equates to one sidereal day(approx 23hr 56min 4sec) to complete a revolution around the earth. This argument is further supported by thinking of the satellite orbit based on the center mass point of the earth being a "single point" in space as the reference and that the satellite orbits that center mass point(point in space not in motion).
This argument is countered with the logic that in order for the geostationary satellite to complete a revolution, its "stationary" position would have to be forgone and either the satellite itself must accelerate or decelerate in relation to the referenced point(earth) in order to complete its revolution; or vice-versa(earth accelerates/decelerates its rotation).
2. Since we are using the earth as the reference point, that the "Geostationary" orbit locks the "0 degree" reference point with the satellite to the ground point and degree reference on earth and as such, a geostationary satellite cannot complete one revolution around earth.
This argument is countered changing the point of view of the observer. If an observer is external to both the earth and it's geostationary satellite, it appears that the satellite will rotate around the earth(not accounting the earth's rotation)


Please help, does a geostationary satellite complete a revolution around the earth? If so, how often?


In the case that you make a video and If you can prove that a geostationary satellite does not make a revolution around the Earth, please say in your video, "Curtis Longoria, you owe 1st Squad Pizza" at some point towards the end.

You could not see with a camera down to the ground using the internal reflection. The photons travel all the way down to the bottom since they are collimated but notmal light is emitted in a diffuse way from every point, so you would lose the information on where every photon was comming from and therefore the information of the actuall image. Of course you would still see the bottom of the rod, but that has nothing to do with the reflection and would also work with a hollow rod with a window at the end

Total internal reflection is definetly cool, and it has real life applications. I work as a fiber optic splicer in Italy building the national fiber optic infrastructure and total internal reflection comes in handy because you can spot damaged parts of the infrastructure with lasers. By looking at the amount of light reflected you can tell if a splice is badly made or if  the fiber is parked in the wrong way (parked because the fiber lies in plastic cards to be protected). In the last case, if the fiber is parked in the wrong way and you see light shining through, you absolutely need to correct the issue cause it means the signal will lose strenght. Another thing that I can think about is that thanks to total internal reflection you can shine lasers up to distances of several kilometers (I have a 30 mw 1650nm laser that reaches up to 30 km. The wavelenght is specific because it doesn't interfere with the signal) and this is helpful to find a specific fiber among hundreds of others. All this while the cables take sometimes sharp turns are rolled up inside manholes.

TIR is why the inside of a glass of drinking water will look a little silvery, but it will get even more silvery when you fill it with water.  Take it a step further, and look down into the glass filled with water, and touch the outside of the glass with your soft moist fingertips. You can see your fingerprints where TIR is broken. TIR is a key element of making computer graphics "ray tracers" look really good.

There are MULTIPLE types of lasers: the word laser began as an acronym for light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation. Lasers can theoretically be built at virtually any electromagnetic frequency, up to and including gamma ray lasers, although we don't have those yet. Lasers produce "light" as a byproduct of their actual function, and devices that are only designed to produce visible light are not technically called lasers.

In the vein of "doing cool stuff with physics" have you ever made a fireball with a tealight? Ok, not quite, but still fun playing with fire. I discovered it accidentally. A used aluminum tealight holder with a bit of wax remaining; old burned matches having absorbed some wax. Light the old matches which act as wicks for the wax, it becomes one large flame like a sterno. Let the wax in the aluminum heat to melting. Let a drop of water fall into the flame. Stand in awe at how bit the fireball was.

Yes, it's a glorified semi-controlled grease fire. Still impressive.

One thing however - if you see the laser along the optical fiber, it means that a significant portion of laser light escapes the fiber, hence it's not the "total internal reflection". When something like this happens to a signal, it deteriorates quite a lot and the fiber must be replaced or at least laid in a different manner, to avoid sharp bends. If everything is ok, then you should see the laser only at the other end of the fiber.

that section with the square acrylic was really interesting. People use leds to side-light acrylic all the time, especially in computer case modeling. The thing is, people always mount them parallel/perpendicular to the square, so it was really cool to see how much brighter of an effect you get when they're mounted at an angle. I'll have to use that in a future project! Also the standing wave you got from shining it into the corner was amazing, too bad you need a really thick piece of acrylic to get that effect.

Hey Destin this experiment reminds me of the concept of polarization by reflection. At 1:55 you mention half the beam punches through the water and half doesn't. I imagine that the light that reflects is preferentially going to be horizontally polarized to the surface of the water, and the light that goes through would be more vertically polarized. This concept drives the theory behind polarized sunglasses, which preferentially block horizontally reflected lights from surfaces. Would you agree?

11:38 - 11:55 No, the laser beam shouldn't "get lighter and lighter". That fading effect on the flashlight bean is the result of the light from the flashlight coming out of the source at a wide range of different angles, some of them reach the critical angle sooner than others, and so break through sooner than others, causing a dimmer reflected beam. This progresses as the flashlight is tilted more and more, more of the different angles coming out are pointed past critical angle, and fade out. But on the laser, there is only 1 angle coming out of the source, so once it passes the critical angle, it should simply vanish as it breaks through, no fading effect at all (other than possibly very very minor fading caused by particular in the water diluting the main beam)

Minor thing: at no angle will the beam punch out of the water completely. A small part will always reflect off of the interface. What's also interesting is that the angles at the interface, and the relative amount of light refracted and reflected, are in fact just perfect to satisfy the conservation of momentum. The light carries momentum after all. You could say that Snell's law is merely a consequence of the conservation of momentum, though Snell couldn't have known that at the time.

- Fill a watering can with water.

I have thought about using a blue or violet laser to make underwater LIDAR. A blue laser could map out a three dimensional picture of nearby objects and terrain underwater. An application might be to help prevent collision for boats in water that is shallow or has obstructions. Might also be used on slow moving submarines in some situations to avoid collisions. The range would be limited but a blue laser would maximize range within the visible spectrum.  A blue wavelength laser would travel further than a green or red laser through water before diverging too much to be practical. Blue lasers also happen to be safer for human eyes because they appear dimmer and human eyes are less sensitive to blue spectrum light, which decreases the range at which it could cause flash blindness. I don't know how sensitive marine life would be to a blue laser but the limited time and location of use may mitigate any hazard to some degree. A boat collision would likely be far more damaging to marine life so preventing collisions may be worth the trade off regardless. A UV laser could have even better range but may present an unacceptable hazard in this application.

an interesting note on snell's law, it what you use to find the most efficient path of motion when you have different speeds (vsauce has a vid on this). Since in this vid you have light travelling through different  you have 2 different "speeds" of light (not actually bc c is universal constant) what you get is what looks like the light bending. what you can do is put light through multiple layers of different mediums and if you layer them from "fastest" to "slowest" you will get a very specific curve known as a brachistochrone.

Very fun episode!  Here's something else really fun and simple you can do with IOR (Index Of Refraction) and lasers. Shine a green or purple laser through a glass of semi clear soda, apple juice, or even a beer. The lasers color changes drastically as it goes through the liquid due to the difference in IOR and the liquids density, but restores to the lasers original color when the light beam re-enters the air and shines on a wall or your hand. The experiment takes mere seconds, but the effect is amazing!

Brings back memories from physics class. We were taught that at a certain critical angle, the emerging light ray is parallel to the surface. We were also taught a bit ago that light ray paths can be reversed (the source and the destination of a light ray can change places and the light will still follow the exact same path). I've wondered since then that if I combine these two, i.e. if I (somehow) shine a laser parallel along the surface, at what point will it (if it will) bend and break into the denser medium?

Hey Dustin, on most of the cases that you showed there is not actual total reflection. Every time the reflected beam is a lot less bright than the incident one it means that a lot of light is escaping the medium; like on the acrylic tube, the only reason we can see it shine is because some the light is escaping. On actual optic fiber (the silicon one), it will look opaque since the main property is that even when bent it is capable of having total reflection.
Also, I don't think you noticed something supper cool that happened during the experiment with the Christmas ornament: the angle of the beam inside the ornament was not the same as the angle of incidence! That's because of the difference in refractive index (which is the same reason total reflection occurs).

I don't know if you know this Communication fiber optics work on the same principle. Fiber optics use a glass rod inside a glass tube. This is all heated together and drawn out as one very long, very thin fiber optic flexible element. A laser is beamed down the center rod and where the laser beam will hit the walls of the center glass rod and the outside glass tube will assist in reflecting the laser beam further back into the the center rod further inline to increase the distance the laser beam will travel farther without amplification. The mating of the molded glass tube and center glass rod produces a sufficient reflective surface to double or triple, (at first when discovered) the beam to travel w/o amplification.

Dude! The reason they say to not look directly into lasers is what you are showing.  With fiber networking, they are using multiple laser frequencies withing the same glass medium (Very cool, multiple wavelengths at the same time on the same medium).  That's why they have all those warnings on the connections.  So, be very careful around lasers.  Even wavelength protecting eyewear can't protect against a direct hit. I have been diving in the inland Cenotes between Playa Del Carmen and Tulum Mexico. This a massive water filled cavern system that is fresh water on top and at about 30-40 feet it turns to salt water creating a halocline.The fresh water is cold but when you go into the salt level it gets warm. If you are below the salt water level and shine your flashlight up it reflects back down from where the fresh and salt water meet. If you mix the fresh and salt water together with your hand it becomes very blurry. I was near the bottom inside the cavern. The sun just happened to be at the correct angle and was shining through a very small hole in the rock roof. The beam of light hit the rock floor below and was a dancing rainbow because my bubbles were causing the water surface to ripple.

Besides Snell's angle, there's also Brewster's angle. I have a heads-up speedometer, which is an LED display that bounces light off the inside of the windshield. A few weeks ago, I went to the eye doctor, who told me I need to wear polarizing sunglasses. I put the sunglasses on and could not read the speedometer! I tilted my head and it reappeared faintly. I figured it was brewstered; later I applied the plastic sheet that came with the speedometer, which, having a different Brewster's angle (or maybe bouncing some off the plastic-glass interface), made the speedometer visible again. Destin, I just stumbled on a process called Laser Microjetting and I think its right up your alley.  It puts together the theory in this video with laminar jets of water.  The device is like a laser cutter, but the laser is shot down a small stream of water to keep the light from being defused.  The interface between the stream and the air causes the laser light to reflect back into the beam.

I do a demo with my students, similar to this. Take a 2 liter empty pop bottle. Poke a small hole near the bottom of the bottle. Fill the bottle with water and have the water, draining from the hole ( should produce a laminar stream of water...who doesn’t like laminar flow???), and have it flow into a sink. Take your laser and shine it through the bottle, opposite to the hole. Aim the laser into the hole of the bottle. You’ll see the laser reflect internally in the stream of water. Where the water hits the bottom of the sink, you’d see a “spot light”. Keep up the great work!

OMG Destin, the moment you said "Look at this beam" my mind went "Oh, I bet he's gonna bounce it off the surface of the water" and as soon as you went "laser + total internal reflection" I was like "Awww yiss he's gonna talk about fiber optics, isn't he?!" And then you busted out that pipe thing and I went to heaven. I was disappointed I couldn't see tiny beams of light bouncing off the edges like in the diagrams we drew in Modern Optics at my highschool. It might be because you only showed the beam going straight on, but it was cool nonetheless. And then the christmas thing was so brilliant (literally!) I was in awe. When you commented about internal reflection not having to be total, I was reminded of when we used a small piece of glass on a stand called--if I'm not mistaken--a "half mirror" or a "beam splitter" that we used because at an angle part of the light was reflected and part was passed through. We used the difference of the two beams' timing to calculate the speed of light, and that remains to this day my favourite physics demonstration I've ever witnessed (and I've seen A LOT). I assume the bulb lights up at that extreme angle because the light gets trapped in the thin film of the bulb as in a fiber optic cable.

But dude, thank you so much for helping me nerd out about physics. I haven't felt this way about physics in a long while, despite watching even your videos! I regularly watch them, and I particularly liked the grain si--erm bin--one, but this one blew me out of the water!

Shout out to Ms. Rebecca Schiller, once a part of BxScience for making highschool physics fun. I have no idea where you are, but I am forever grateful for your tutelage.

This Total Internal Reflectance must be why an FTIR chemistry instrument with an HATR attachment bounces the IR signal along the internal surfaces of the crystal. I actually learned about this in a physics class last semester it's really cool. Another thing we learned at the same time was the way the angle of the light changes when changing from two materials with different indexes of refraction. A common example of this is to stick a pencil in a glass of water and see how the pencil seems to distort. I believe the formula was{ angle1 * index1 = angle2 * index 2 }you could use that laser and acrylic to test this formula and my memory of the formula. Just remember the formula is only for the angle from one medium to the next meaning if you were to measure the angle from just before the acrylic to just after the angle would not change since angle1*index1(air) = angle2 * index2(acrylic) = angle3* index 3(acrylic) (angle 1 must = angle 3 since index 1 and 3 are both air = roughly 1) .

Welcome to the basics of optical fiber my children this is how you get your internet now

This snell's window thing is the reason why you shouldn't bend optical data cables too much. The fibre is actually made of multiple layers with different refractive indices. The inner strand is where the data shines through, and it reflects off its walls. If the bend is too sharp it has the potential to leak out into the other layers, but because in leaking, it's also being bent, the ray should reflect of the boundary to the next layer, hopefully staying in that layer, maybe even getting back into the core (though that's minimal) and getting to the other end that way. There are some more layers of cladding around that, but they're mainly for structural integrity.


And obviously, if you bend the fibre too much, all of the light will leak because you eventually will break the fibre, but they're surprisingly flexible.

At 1:15 the sentence "you can only see the sun at a certain angle" is a bit ambiguous, so just to clarify:

This does not mean that you can't see the sun, if it is below a certain point.
You can see the sun from underneath the surface, no matter how high it is in the sky.
Snells window simply warps the whole 180° hemisphere into a ~97° window with little distortion when looking straight up and much distortion towards the edge.

Instead it means that the sun always appears to be at an angle of at least ~41° (measured from the horizon) when you are under water.

Snell's law applies to more than flashlights and lasers. It also describes how seismic waves bounce, reflect, refract, etc. inside the earth. The boundaries there are based on density, and there's more than one might think. From the hypocenter to a given point on the surface, one can trace the wave's path as a line (not unlike a laser), and if it's clear enough trace secondary, tertiary, etc. waves as well. The really cool thing though is that between boundaries, there's still a density gradient, so everything curves upwards as it travels.

8:15 No, you can not really use this as a camera because focus is still a thing. Well, I mean, if you polish it precisely and attach it to a good microscope, then it will work, although still not perfectly.

You can squish a ton of thin optic fibers in a long rod, and then you can see the image on the other end as if it was close. But the thing you are looking at has to be relatively flat (light beams perpendicular to the surface) because otherwise you won't see anything because of focus. So a book or LCD screen will work, but looking at riverbed will be mostly just blur.

Fibre optic cable consists of a core and a cladding (outer later of glass that reflects the light back into the core). Because of the cladding, you will not be able to see the light until it exits the end. If you can see light in the cable it’s not working properly. The cladding prevents any light from exiting the core just as the surface of the water is doing....if anyone cares lol.

Total internal reflection is at the core of making an attractive faceter gemstone. The primary (but not only) goal when designing a cut for a stone is to maximize light from above TIRing a couple times and returning to the eye. (People like me who cut coloured stone often design a cut for each stone they cut).

Oh and by coloured stone, I should say metal oxide mineral in a specific crystalline habit with trace elements which confer color (and often pleochroism)... what with this being SmarterEveryDay.
